Xi'an Key Laboratory of Functional Organic Porous Materials School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Northwestern Polytechnical University Xi'an 710129 PR China Catalyst stability is believed to be one of the greatest challenges faced for the supported metal catalysts in the catalytic conversion of biomass and its derivatives because many biomass transformations are conducted in the aqueous phase. In this work, we report a simple yet efficient coating-impregnation-pyrolysis (CIP) strategy to fabricate Al2O3 supported Ru catalyst (Ru-Al2O3@CN) with Ru NPs (nanoparticles) semi-embedded into N-doped carbon (CN) layer for the efficient hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone in the aqueous phase. Benefit from the special structure of Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, it possesses both high catalytic activity and stability, giving a TOF of 28,099 h-1 for LA hydrogenation at 120 °C and 2 MPa H2, which is superior to the most of reported Ru-based catalysts. More importantly, compared with conventional impregnated Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst exhibits a remarkably improved hydrothermal stability. Based on series of catalyst characterizations and control experiments, it was found that the presence of CN can weak the interaction between Ru and Al2O3, as well as protect the Al2O3 and Ru NPs from hydrolysis and aggregation, respectively. We anticipate that such a novel strategy may provide some valuable insights into the synthesis of oxides-supported metal catalyst with high hydrothermal stability. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Catalyst stability Levulinic acid Coating-impregnation-pyrolysis strategy Embedded structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Heterogeneous catalyst constitutes a vital part in the modern chemical industry, from refinery to pharmaceuticals [1,2]. From the viewpoint of industrial application, activity, selectivity, and stability are the three most important indexes of heterogeneous catalysts [3]. Nowadays, the activity and selectivity of a heterogeneous catalyst are frequently served as the screening criteria to drive catalyst development. There is no doubt that for a heterogeneous catalyst, the starting activity and selectivity is of great significance. However, it's also worth noting that the activity and selectivity must be coupled with adequate catalyst stability from the viewpoint of practical application in the future [4,5]. For example, the costs used for catalyst replacement and process shutdown reach up to total billions of dollars every year due to the deactivation of heterogeneous catalysts [6,7]. Catalyst stability, therefore, is a problem of great and continuing concern in the practice of industrial catalytic processes. Currently, for supported metal catalysts, their stability often suffers from three challenges in the condensed phase. Firstly, supported metal nanoparticles will agglomerate to larger particles at high temperature because of their high surface free energy [8–10]. In fact, the metal aggregation is common in gas-phase reactions at high temperature, such as methane dry reforming [11], reverse water gas shift (RWGS) [12], and hydrocarbon cracking [13]. Furthermore, the growth of metal nanoparticles can also exist in some aqueous-phase reactions [14]. Secondly, in some cases, the metal leaching may occur because of the following reasons. The supported metal can directly dissolve into an acidic reaction solution. Additionally, some chemical transformations such as hydrolysis and formation of a complex between the metal and reaction species or solvent may happen in condensed-phase reactions, which also can lead to the leaching of supported metal [15,16]. Last but not least, the hydrolysis or collapse of oxide support usually happens under hydrothermal conditions. For conventional oxides, such as γ-Al2O3 and mesoporous silica (SBA-15), hydrolysis or collapse of ordered structure during the aqueous-phase reaction process have been widely reported [17–19]. Moreover, it should be noted that the support hydrolysis or collapse could also cause the sintering and/or leaching of supported metal nanoparticles, which would exacerbate the catalyst deactivation [20]. Based on the above discussion, it can be found that the development of oxide supported metal catalysts with high hydrothermal stability is extremely challenging. To solve the above discussed issues, many efforts have been made. Firstly, fabricating the catalyst with strong metal-support interaction is widely used to improve the catalyst resistance against sintering and/or leaching. For example, Huber et al. reported that no detectable loss and aggregation of cobalt were found for the TiOy-overcoated cobalt catalysts after 105 h time-on-stream test at 140 °C [21]. However, once the reaction temperature reaches above 200 °C, the TiO2 support also undergo hydrolysis, causing the decrease of catalytic activity. The second strategy is to coat the oxide support or oxide supported metal catalyst by carbon layer [13,16,22–25]. Carbon coating on alumina and silica has been proved to be an effective way to improve their hydrothermal stability [16]. However, for the catalyst with metal/oxide@C structure, the surface carbon layer in oxide@C exhibits much higher chemical inertness in comparison with pristine oxide support, which leads to a weaker metal-support interaction, thus making the supported metal prone to sintering and/or loss during the catalyst preparation and/or reaction process [13]. For the catalyst with (metal/oxide)@C structure, both oxide support hydrolysis and metal particle sintering, leaching could be effectively suppressed, while the presence of carbon layer may block part of active sites sometimes, and thus leading to a decreased activity. For example, Li et al. reported that the carbon shells with an appropriate thickness for the CNFx@Ni@CNTs catalyst is a crucial point to obtain the best catalytic performance [26]. Last but not least, embedding metal nanoparticles into the support has also been found to be an effective way to stabilize metal nanoparticles [4,27–32]. This structure endows the catalyst with both high catalytic activity and sintering resistance of metal NPs. Unfortunately, this strategy can also hardly solve the hydrothermal stability of oxide support. Therefore, the development of a facile strategy to fabricate the oxide supported metal catalyst with both high catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability is highly desirable but still a significant challenge. In this work, a simple yet efficient coating-impregnation-pyrolysis strategy was developed to fabricate supported Ru catalysts (Ru-Al2O3@CN) with Ru NPs semi-embedded into N-doped carbon layer. The fresh Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity for LA hydrogenation in aqueous phase at 120 °C and 2 MPa H2, giving a TOF of 28,099 h−1. To the best of our knowledge, this is superior to most of the reported Ru-based catalysts under similar reaction conditions (Table S1). More importantly, compared with traditional impregnated Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, the presence of semi-embedded Ru particles in N-doped carbon layer structure can improve significantly the hydrothermal stability of Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst prepared by CIP strategy. 2 Results and discussion Compared with conventional hard-template method for the fabrication of semi-embedded metal catalysts [33–36], the key point of CIP strategy is the presence of polydopamine (PDA) on the surface of Al2O3. During pyrolysis process, the PDA will be transformed into porous N-doped carbon layer, which can weaken the attack of H2O molecule in the aqueous-phase reaction, and thus improving the hydrothermal stability of support. More importantly, the PDA layer exhibits a small volume shrinkage during pyrolysis process in compared with small molecules [37–39]. Thus, after the impregnation of RuCl3 into the pore of PDA, the core-shell structure with Ru NPs completely encapsulated by carbon layer can be effectively inhibited. The synthesis procedure was illustrated in Scheme 1 . Typically, the self-polymerization of dopamine hydrochloride (DA·HCl) catalyzed by tris (hydroxymethyl) aminomethane (Tris) was first coated on the surface of Al2O3 for 12 h to obtained Al2O3@PDA composites. Subsequently, RuCl3 was impregnated into Al2O3@PDA to get RuCl3-Al2O3@PDA precursor. Finally, the RuCl3-Al2O3@PDA precursor was pyrolyzed at 800 °C in nitrogen atmosphere to obtain Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst. For comparison, the traditional impregnated Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/(Al2O3@CN) catalysts, and (Ru/Al2O3)@CN catalyst with (metal/oxide)@C structure were also prepared through similar procedure (as shown in Scheme 1). The N2 sorption experiments were first conducted to investigate the influence of different preparation methods on the physicochemical properties of various Ru catalysts. All of the Ru catalysts exhibit a very similar type-IV isotherm (Fig. 1a ), indicating that they may have almost the same pore volume with the presence of mesoporous structure. To be exact, the BET surface area (Table 1 ) increase in the following order: (Ru/Al2O3)@CN (156.6 m2/g) ≈ Ru-Al2O3@CN (152.8 m2/g) ≈ Ru/(Al2O3@CN) (150.8 m2/g) > Ru/Al2O3 (122.8 m2/g). This result implies that the introduction of CN is beneficial to improve the surface area of catalyst, which is in line with TEM results (Fig. 2 ) that the N-doped carbon layer on the Al2O3 surface is porous and defective. Moreover, various Ru catalysts also possess almost the same pore volume (Table 1). It should be noted that the high pore volume and average pore size may mainly result from the gaps between the alumina particles because the Al2O3 used in this work is nano-sized (as shown in Figs. 2a and S1) [40]. The above discussion shows that the catalyst surface area and pore volume might be not the main reason for the different catalytic performance of various Ru catalysts for the LA hydrogenation. Subsequently, the XRD analysis was performed to study the Ru dispersion of various Ru catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1b, no peak corresponding to metallic Ru could be detected for all samples, which might be ascribed to the high Ru dispersion and/or the low Ru content. TEM analysis (Figs. 2a and S1) confirms that all samples possess excellent Ru dispersion with similar mean size. ICP-OES analysis (Table S2) indicates that various Ru catalysts also have similar Ru content from 0.81 to 0.99 wt%. The structure of the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst was further investigated by HRTEM and STEM-EDS analysis. All Ru particles are homogeneously distributed on the surface with a mean size of 1.78 nm (Fig. 2a and 2d). The different planes of Ru in Ru-Al2O3@CN, which are the bright spots as shown in Fig. 2b, could be found in the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns by using a comparative d spacings method. More importantly, further HRTEM analysis shows that the Al2O3 support is encapsulated by defective carbon layer with a thickness of around 1.3 nm, indicating that the N-doped carbon layer (CN) is successfully introduced on the Al2O3 surface (Fig. 2c). Additionally, STEM-EDS demonstrates that Ru, C, and N atoms are homogeneously distributed in the whole sample, further confirming the successful fabrication of Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst with Ru particles semi-embedded into N-doped carbon layer structure (Fig. 3 ). More information through the shifting of reduction temperature could be obtained by H2-TPR-MS to elucidate the interaction between metal and support. As can be seen from Fig. 4a , the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst shows a broad peak around 670 °C, which might be attributed to the reduction of partial Ru species with strong interaction with Al2O3. For the Ru/(Al2O3@CN) catalyst, the peak (110 °C) belonging to the reduction of Run+ to Ru0 is far lower than that of Ru/Al2O3 catalyst because of the low interaction between Ru species and Al2O3@CN, indicating that the presence of N-doped carbon layer can weaken considerably the interaction of Ru species with Al2O3. Additionally, the difference in metal-support interaction can be confirmed by the mass signal (Fig. 4b). It has been widely reported that Ru can easily catalyze the methanation of carbon at high temperature [28,29]. Among various Ru catalysts, the (Ru/Al2O3)@CN exhibits the lowest initial methanation temperature (about 300 °C), which is resulted from the intimate contact of Ru NPs with N-doped carbon layer. For the Ru/(Al2O3@CN) catalyst, the initial methanation temperature is about 450 °C due to the weak interaction between Ru and CN. As expected, the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst with Ru NPs semi-embedded into N-doped carbon structure presents a moderate initial methanation temperature (380 °C) because its moderate interaction in comparison with Ru/(Al2O3@CN) and (Ru/Al2O3)@CN catalysts. To make a further study of the interaction between metal and support for various Ru catalysts, XPS analysis was then carried out and the binding energies was calibrated with the reference C 1 s (284.6 eV) spectral line. As shown in Figs. S2a, the Ru 3p signal intensity decreases in the following order: Ru/(Al2O3@CN) > Ru-Al2O3@CN > Ru/Al2O3 > (Ru/Al2O3)@CN. For the (Ru/Al2O3)@CN catalyst, the lowest Ru 3p signal intensity might be mainly resulted from part of Ru species covered by N-doped carbon layer because of its (metal/oxide)@C structure. Interestingly, although the Ru nanoparticles are highly dispersed on the support surface for both conventional impregnated Ru/(Al2O3@CN) and Ru/Al2O3 catalysts, the Ru/(Al2O3@CN) catalyst possesses much higher Ru 3p signal intensity in comparison with that of the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst. This might be attributed to the different interaction strength between Ru and support, which is in line with the H2-TPR-MS results. Furthermore, this conclusion can be confirmed by the proportion of Ru0 species in various Ru catalysts. To be exact, the proportion of Ru0 for the Ru/Al2O3 and (Ru/Al2O3)@CN catalysts is 57.3 % and 58.3 %, respectively. The low Ru0 proportion is mainly ascribed to the high Ru-Al2O3 interaction, which making ruthenium oxide difficult to reduce during pyrolysis process. As expected, for the Ru/(Al2O3@CN) and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts with low Ru-Al2O3 interaction, the proportion of Ru0 is 60.9 % and 64.7 %, respectively, which are higher than that of Ru/Al2O3 and (Ru/Al2O3)@CN catalysts. The Ru-CN interaction can be investigated by N 1 s spectra (Fig. S2b). Compared with Ru/(Al2O3@CN) and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts, the binding energy of N 1 s of (Ru/Al2O3)@CN catalyst positively shift because of the higher Ru-CN interaction, which is consistent with H2-TPR-MS results. It can be, therefore, further confirmed that the presence of CN can weaken the interaction between Ru and Al2O3, which is beneficial to the formation of metallic Ru. Levulinic acid, as a promising, sustainable platform molecule, can be produced easily and economically from lignocellulosic biomass via a simple and robust hydrolysis process [41–45]. Thus, the catalytic performance of various Ru catalysts was initially investigated at 100 °C and 2 MPa H2 using the hydrogenation of levulinic acid in aqueous solution (Table 2 ). Notably, 15 % LA conversion could be achieved over pure Al2O3 (Table 2, entry 1), which might result from the LA in aqueous phase reacts with Al2O3, producing some unknown products. This also confirms that the Al2O3 support is very unstable under this reaction conditions. However, the LA conversion resulted from the reaction of LA and Al2O3 over Al2O3@CN decreases to 6 % (Table 2, entry 2), far lower than that of pure Al2O3, indicating the protective effect of N-doped carbon layer. Additionally, the above results also confirm that the Ru species in various Ru catalysts are the active sites for the transformation of LA into γ-valerolactone. Among various Ru catalysts, the (Ru/Al2O3)@CN catalyst exhibits the lowest LA conversion, giving a TOF (turnover frequency) of 199 h−1. Considering the fact that most of Ru NPs in (Ru/Al2O3)@CN might be covered by the N-doped carbon layer derived from PDA, it's reasonable that it shows the lowest catalytic activity. Interestingly, the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst with Ru NPs semi-embedded into N-doped carbon layer structure displays higher TOF (2525 h−1) than that of traditional impregnated Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/(Al2O3@CN) catalysts. More importantly, it should be noted that although the impregnated Ru/Al2O3 catalyst shows a high LA conversion, the selectivity for γ-valerolactone is only 26 %, which is due to the transformation of LA is mainly ascribed to the reaction between LA and Al2O3 in Ru/Al2O3 catalyst. For the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, the γ-valerolactone selectivity is up to 79 %, implying that the presence of N-doped carbon could remarkably improve the hydrothermal stability of Al2O3 in Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst. It can be, therefore, concluded that the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst prepared by CIP strategy is the best among various Ru catalysts for the LA hydrogenation in the aqueous phase. When the reaction temperature increases to 120 °C, the TOF for the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst could reach 4923 h−1 (Table 2, entry 7). To measure the intrinsic activity of the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, the TOF was also calculated based on the number of active sites determined by CO chemisorption and at low γ-valerolactone yield (<10 %). Notably, the TOF could reach up to 28,099 h−1 at 120 °C, which, to the best of our knowledge, outperforms other reported Ru-based catalysts for the same reaction under similar reaction conditions (Fig. 5a and Table S1). Next, The stability of Ru-Al2O3@CN and Ru/Al2O3 catalysts was firstly examined under mild reaction conditions: LA 1.0 g, H2O 5 mL, 100 °C and 2 MPa H2. As shown in Fig. 5b, for Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, it shows an obvious decrease in catalytic activity even after first cycle, with a steady decline in LA conversion from 60 % to 31 %, and then dropping to 17 % in the third cycle. As expected, the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst exhibits a significant enhanced stability and can be reused at least 6 times (Fig. 5c). Interestingly, after 3 cycles, the LA conversion increases from 61 % to 72 %. Subsequently, the LA conversion presents a slow increase trend as the number of cycles increased. Next, the recycle test of Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst was then operated under harsh reaction conditions (LA 2.0 g, H2O 4 mL, 120 °C and 2 MPa H2). As shown in Fig. 5d, for the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, it still shows a high stability and can be reused at least 5 times even at high LA concentration and reaction temperature. It should be noted that the catalytic activity of Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst also displays a gradual increase tendency with increasing number of catalytic cycles, which is similar with its stability test at 100 °C and 2 MPa H2. Based on above results, it can be found that the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst seems to have a slow release effect, which will be clarified in the following part. To understand the discrepancy in catalyst stability performance between the Ru/Al2O3 and Ru-Al2O3@CN, series of catalyst characterizations and control experiments were performed. It can be seen from Fig. 6a that the XRD patterns of spent Ru/Al2O3 and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts are almost same as corresponding fresh samples. In other words, there seems no change of support structure observed after stability testing, which is in contradiction of the fact that part of Al2O3 could react with LA during the reaction for both the Ru/Al2O3 and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts. This might be mainly resulted from the fact that the hydrolyzed or reacted Al2O3 is in situ dissolved into the reaction solution, and thus the remaining parts in spent Ru/Al2O3 and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts are not hydrolyzed Al2O3. Based on the TEM analysis (Fig. 6b), it was found that the mean size of Ru particles for the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst after 3 cycles increases to 2.32 nm with a wide size distribution, which is much larger than that of fresh Ru/Al2O3 catalyst (1.77 nm, as shown in Fig. S1). In contrast, the mean Ru size for spent Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst is almost the same as the fresh one (Fig. 6c), implying the high hydrothermal stability of Ru particles semi-embedded into N-doped carbon layer. The aggregation of Ru NPs in spent Ru/Al2O3 catalyst might be mainly attributed to the support (Al2O3) hydrolysis and collapse. Liu et al. also reported that the collapsed mesoporous structure for LaNiO3/MCM-41 could cause metal aggregation to certain extent [46]. After that, the lattice spacings of Al2O3 in Ru/Al2O3 catalyst before and after reaction were measured by high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) to further confirm the change of Al2O3 crystal phase structure. As shown in Fig. 6e, for the fresh Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, the distance between two lattice fringes was calculated to be 0.247 and 0.204 nm, which is assigned to (311) and (400) planes for γ-Al2O3 respectively. However, after 3 recycling runs, most of the lattice spacings observed in spent Ru/Al2O3–3 catalyst are belonged to (200) planes of AlO(OH) and (013) planes of Al(OH)3 (Fig. 6f), which further confirms that the Al2O3 in Ru/Al2O3 catalyst undergoes severe hydrolysis during the stability test process. To investigate the anti-leaching ability of Ru/Al2O3 and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts, the Ru and Al contents of spent catalysts after stability testing at 100 °C and 2 MPa H2 were investigated by ICP-OES (Fig. 6d). For the spent Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, both the Ru and Al contents decrease in compared with fresh Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, which might be mainly attributed to the serious hydrolysis and then dissolution of Al2O3. Gallezot et al. also reported that in some liquid phase reactions, the loss of active component from catalysts is mainly resulted from support leaching [47]. Surprisingly, the Ru content for the spent Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst after 6 recycling tests increases from 0.83 to 1.06 wt%, while the Al content exhibits an opposite trend. The obvious increase in Ru content might be ascribed to the Ru NPs embedded into N-doped carbon layer (CN) are stable and do not leach even though part of Al2O3 support dissolves into the reaction solution. In view of the fact that the loss of patrial Al2O3 might liberate some Ru sites covered by Al2O3, the CO chemisorption of Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst before and after reaction was performed (Table S3). Compared with the fresh Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, both the CO uptake and metal area notably increase for the spent Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, indicating the enhanced Ru exposure. Meanwhile, it's worth to noting that the improved catalytic activity during stability testing for Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst might be attributed to the increased Ru content and Ru exposure. To further study the metal leaching of Ru/Al2O3 and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts, the reaction solution after each cycle was collected (Fig. 7 ). It should be noted that the catalyst usage is 100 mg during the first cycle in order to make the phenomenon more obvious. As shown in Table S4, both Al leaching was observed for Ru/Al2O3 and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts, but the loss of Al in Ru/Al2O3 is more serious, which is consistent with the reaction results of Al2O3 and Al2O3@CN (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). The reaction solution is clear and transparent before reaction, but it becomes turbid with light grey after undergoing 1st cycle for the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 7a), demonstrating that part of the hydrolysate dissolves in reaction solution. Similar phenomenon has also been reported previously for the MgO supported PdCu catalyst [48]. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 7b, the color of the reaction solution becomes much darker for the 2nd recycling run, implying that the spent Ru/Al2O3 catalyst with the structure of patrial Al2O3 changed to AlO(OH) and Al(OH)3 is more prone to dissolve into reaction solution. In contrast, for the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, the reaction solution is still clear and colorless even after 3 recycling runs, indicating that no Ru leaching happens during the reaction process. This conclusion can be confirmed by the fact that there is no Ru detected in reaction solution for the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, as shown in Table S4. Additionally, after the removal of solvent in the reaction solution derived from the 2nd cycle, grey precipitation (denoted as Ru/Al2O3–2-P) was obtained. Subsequently, the precipitate (Ru/Al2O3–2-P) was analyzed by XRD (Fig. 7 g). It was found that the peaks belonging to γ-Al2O3 becomes very weak, implying that the precipitate is mainly the product of complete hydrolysis of Al2O3. Based on above discussion, it can be, therefore, concluded that the Al2O3 support in Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst not only possesses high acid-resistance, the Ru particles but also has both anti-sintering and anti-leaching properties. From the above discussion, a mechanism for the stability of Ru/Al2O3 and Ru-Al2O3@CN catalysts was proposed (Fig. 8 ). For the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, the Al2O3 support may suffer from serious hydrolysis first during the reaction process in aqueous phase, and then partial hydrolyzed Al2O3 is dissolved into the reaction solution. Meanwhile, the Ru NPs on the Al2O3 surface will be also leached into the reaction solution, leading to the low hydrothermal stability of Ru/Al2O3 catalyst. Interestingly, for the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst with Ru particles semi-embedded into N-doped carbon layer structure, the hydrolysis of Al2O3 during the reaction process can be suppressed remarkable because of the physical protection of N-doped carbon layer. More importantly, due to the special semi-embedded structure, Ru particles are stable during stability test and not leached into the reaction solution. Furthermore, more Ru species will be accessible to the reactants because the slight loss of Al2O3 during the reaction process can liberate in situ some active sites covered by Al2O3 support, which seems to be a slow release process. Therefore, the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst exhibits high hydrothermal stability for the LA conversion in aqueous phase. 3 Conclusion In conclusion, we have reported a facile strategy to fabricate Al2O3 supported Ru catalyst (Ru-Al2O3@CN) with Ru particles semi-embedded into N-doped carbon layer structure for the efficient hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone in the aqueous phase. Compared with impregnated Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/(Al2O3@CN), and overcoated (Ru/Al2O3)@CN catalysts, the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst exhibits higher catalytic activity, giving a TOF of 28,099 h−1 for LA hydrogenation at 120 °C and 2 MPa H2. More importantly, the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst shows much higher hydrothermal stability at 100 °C and 2 MPa H2 in comparison with Ru/Al2O3 catalyst. Additionally, a slow improvement in catalytic activity after recycling test was observed. Based on control experiments and characterizations, a possible mechanism of slow release of Ru sites by alumina leaching during stability test was proposed, demonstrating that the presence of N-doped carbon layer with strong Ru-C interaction is the main reason for the excellent hydrothermal stability. This facile strategy for the fabrication of oxide-metal-carbon catalysts may provide a new choice to design and synthesize oxides-supported metal catalysts with high hydrothermal stability for other reactions. coredata.dc:description: Catalyst stability is believed to be one of the greatest challenges faced for the supported metal catalysts in the catalytic conversion of biomass and its derivatives because many biomass transformations are conducted in the aqueous phase. In this work, we report a simple yet efficient coating-impregnation-pyrolysis (CIP) strategy to fabricate Al2O3 supported Ru catalyst (Ru-Al2O3@CN) with Ru NPs (nanoparticles) semi-embedded into N-doped carbon (CN) layer for the efficient hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone in the aqueous phase. Benefit from the special structure of Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst, it possesses both high catalytic activity and stability, giving a TOF of 28,099 h-1 for LA hydrogenation at 120 °C and 2 MPa H2, which is superior to the most of reported Ru-based catalysts. More importantly, compared with conventional impregnated Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, the Ru-Al2O3@CN catalyst exhibits a remarkably improved hydrothermal stability. Based on series of catalyst characterizations and control experiments, it was found that the presence of CN can weak the interaction between Ru and Al2O3, as well as protect the Al2O3 and Ru NPs from hydrolysis and aggregation, respectively. We anticipate that such a novel strategy may provide some valuable insights into the synthesis of oxides-supported metal catalyst with high hydrothermal stability.

coredata.dc:title: Enhanced hydrothermal stability by a semi-embedded structure: An efficient Ru catalyst for levulinic acid conversion in the aqueous phase
